Award.AwardTitle: HBCU-UP TIP: Increasing and Retaining Computer Science majors at Hampton University through Computational Thinking and Curriculum Reformation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Hampton University proposes to implement an HBCU-UP Targeted Infusion Project to reform three computer science gateway courses and to develop an intensive computing summer bridge program for computer science, engineering, and mathematics majors in an effort to enhance student academic performance, increase retention, and improve graduation rates, particularly for computer science students. The PIs propose to strengthen the students' problem-solving and critical thinking skills by integrating computational thinking into lower-level courses. This strategy will be coupled with a pre-college summer program that will be designed to inculcate the prerequisite skills among prospective students for success in the gateway courses.

The proposed project is in response to observable enrollment and course completion data, results of academic support programs, and student surveys. It will implement a cyclical model as the framework to integrate computational thinking and programming concepts in learning modules and to assess learning outcomes. Faculty also will employ and assess the impact of learning techniques that have been proven effective for STEM students and develop future concepts relevant for Hampton and other institutions seeking to address similar problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Department of Computer Science at Hampton University implemented an HBCU-UP Targeted Infusion Project to (a) reform three computer science gateway courses and (b) develop an intensive computing summer bridge program for computer science, engineering, and mathematics majors in an effort to enhance student academic performance, increase retention, and improve graduation rates, particularly for computer science students. The PIs strengthened the students’ problem-solving and critical thinking skills by integrating computational thinking into lower-level courses (CSC 151, CSC 152, and CSC 251; equivalent to CS1, CS2, and CS3). This strategy was coupled with a summer computing pre-college program that was designed to inculcate the prerequisite skills among prospective students for success in the gateway courses. A supplement funding was requested for an Undergraduate Research Initiative focusing on freshmen students and topics related to impact of technology in non-computing fields.

The following are overall accomplishments:

1)      Summer Computing Pre-College Program:

  • Computer Science Readiness: The Summer Program provided students with analytical, problem solving, and program development skills necessary to successfully matriculate through the Computer Science curriculum. Overall results of students passing CS3 for the first time taking are not significant: 60% passing in Fall 2014 compared to 58% passing in Fall 2016 (doubled enrollment). With the number of students increase in the program (as a result of the Summer Computing Pre-College, 50% enrollment increase in CS3), higher number of students enrolled in and passed CS3.
  • Math Readiness:  The Summer Program provided students with Math readiness for Fall semester – the curriculum in Computer Science required students to be in Pre-Calculus I in Fall semester. Therefore, students attending College Algebra (MAT 105) during summer was able to start their major curriculum as they rolled in Fall semester.  Consequently, this increases the enrollment in our gateway courses (20% of students were able to take CS1 because they fulfilled MAT requirement during summer). 
  • Career Readiness: The Summer Program hosted guest speakers from industries as well as academia. This allows students to see the impact of computer science in all fields of students and everything in their daily lives.  Because of their attendance in the summer, the students have more opportunities to apply and acquire for summer internship positions. Approximately 50% of students attended the Summer Program who remains in majors obtained summer internship during their freshmen year.

 

2)      Gateways Course Reformation: Although the first-time completion rate in gateway courses have no significant increase; the enrollment numbers and first-time passing numbers have significantly increase comparing number prior to the reformation. CS1 has 40% enrollment increase, with a consistent total of 55-60 students in Fall semester;  CS2 has 50% enrollment increase, with a consistent total of 35-40 students in Spring semester; CS3 has 50% enrollment increase, with a consistent total of 25-30 students in Fall semester.   

 

3)      Undergraduate Research Initiative: The number of freshmen research has increased 100%, where all freshmen were engaged in research starting from Fall 2014, and 5 groups of students have continued and presented their posters in Spring 2016 (a total of 15 students, 5 are non-computer science students).  The second cohort of students started their research from Fall 2016, and 14 groups: 10 poster presentations, 3 oral presentations, and 1 peer-review paper (a total of 33 students, 14 are non-computer science students).

 

4)      Sustainability for Summer Computing Pre-College Program:  The Department of Computer Science at Hampton University solicited and received commitment from Lockheed Martin, Accenture, and Yahoo to sponsor students to the Hampton University Computer Science Pre-College Program during Summer 2016 and 2017. As a result of Summer Program in previous years, Google provided additional support enabled us to offer the Summer 2017 Computing Pre-College Program to incoming freshmen at Howard University and Morgan State University. Additional industries partners have been solicited to facilitate the continuity of this Computing Pre-College program.

 

Selected Publication:

Muhammad, J., & Boonthum-Denecke, C. (2015). Computing Pre-College Program: Initial Impact to First-Year Student Computer Science. STARS Celebration and RESPECT 2015, Charlotte, NC, August 13-15, 2015, IEEE.  DOI: https://doi.org/10.1109/RESPECT.2015.7296523

Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The Department of Computer Science at Hampton University implemented an HBCU-UP Targeted Infusion Project to (a) reform three computer science gateway courses and (b) develop an intensive computing summer bridge program for computer science, engineering, and mathematics majors in an effort to enhance student academic performance, increase retention, and improve graduation rates, particularly for computer science students. The PIs strengthened the students? problem-solving and critical thinking skills by integrating computational thinking into lower-level courses (CSC 151, CSC 152, and CSC 251; equivalent to CS1, CS2, and CS3). This strategy was coupled with a summer computing pre-college program that was designed to inculcate the prerequisite skills among prospective students for success in the gateway courses. A supplement funding was requested for an Undergraduate Research Initiative focusing on freshmen students and topics related to impact of technology in non-computing fields. The following are overall accomplishments: 1) Summer Computing Pre-College Program: Computer Science Readiness: The Summer Program provided students with analytical, problem solving, and program development skills necessary to successfully matriculate through the Computer Science curriculum. Overall results of students passing CS3 for the first time taking are not significant: 60% passing in Fall 2014 compared to 58% passing in Fall 2016 (doubled enrollment). With the number of students increase in the program (as a result of the Summer Computing Pre-College, 50% enrollment increase in CS3), higher number of students enrolled in and passed CS3. Math Readiness: The Summer Program provided students with Math readiness for Fall semester – the curriculum in Computer Science required students to be in Pre-Calculus I in Fall semester. Therefore, students attending College Algebra (MAT 105) during summer was able to start their major curriculum as they rolled in Fall semester. Consequently, this increases the enrollment in our gateway courses (20% of students were able to take CS1 because they fulfilled MAT requirement during summer). Career Readiness: The Summer Program hosted guest speakers from industries as well as academia. This allows students to see the impact of computer science in all fields of students and everything in their daily lives. Because of their attendance in the summer, the students have more opportunities to apply and acquire for summer internship positions. Approximately 50% of students attended the Summer Program who remains in majors obtained summer internship during their freshmen year. 2) Gateways Course Reformation: Although the first-time completion rate in gateway courses have no significant increase; the enrollment numbers and first-time passing numbers have significantly increase comparing number prior to the reformation. CS1 has 40% enrollment increase, with a consistent total of 55-60 students in Fall semester; CS2 has 50% enrollment increase, with a consistent total of 35-40 students in Spring semester; CS3 has 50% enrollment increase, with a consistent total of 25-30 students in Fall semester. 3) Undergraduate Research Initiative: The number of freshmen research has increased 100%, where all freshmen were engaged in research starting from Fall 2014, and 5 groups of students have continued and presented their posters in Spring 2016 (a total of 15 students, 5 are non-computer science students). The second cohort of students started their research from Fall 2016, and 14 groups: 10 poster presentations, 3 oral presentations, and 1 peer-review paper (a total of 33 students, 14 are non-computer science students). 4) Sustainability for Summer Computing Pre-College Program: The Department of Computer Science at Hampton University solicited and received commitment from Lockheed Martin, Accenture, and Yahoo to sponsor students to the Hampton University Computer Science Pre-College Program during Summer 2016 and 2017. As a result of Summer Program in previous years, Google provided additional support enabled us to offer the Summer 2017 Computing Pre-College Program to incoming freshmen at Howard University and Morgan State University. Additional industries partners have been solicited to facilitate the continuity of this Computing Pre-College program. Selected Publication: Muhammad, J., & Boonthum-Denecke, C. (2015).
